questions.Question: Which one of the following is a major green house gas?
questions.solution: Solution:		A greenhouse gas (sometimes abbreviated GHG) is a gas in an atmosphere that absorbs and emits radiation within the thermal infrared range. This process is the fundamental cause of the greenhouse effect. The primary greenhouse gases in the Earth’s atmosphere are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone. In the Solar System, the atmospheres of Venus, Mars, and Titan also contain gases that cause greenhouse effects. Greenhouse gases greatly affect the temperature of the Earth; without them, Earth’s surface would average about 33 degree C (91 degree F) colder than the present average of 14 degree C (57 degree F). Atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases are determined by the balance between sources (emissions of the gas from human activities and natural systems) and sinks (the removal of the gas from the atmosphere by conversion to a different chemical compound). The proportion of an emission remaining in the atmosphere after a specified time is the “Airborne fraction” (AF).

questions.Question: The 'solid waste' is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'solid waste' is also known as sludge.

questions.Question: Spirit in contact with body gives cool sensation because it is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Spirit is very volatile. So when it is exposed, it evaporates rapidly to the air if released into the environment, producing a cool effect.

questions.Question: Which one is a sublime substance?
questions.solution: Solution:		Iodine is a sublimate.

questions.Question: The biogas used for cooking is a mixture of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Biogas is essentially a mixture of Methane (CH4, around 55-75%) but also contains Carbon Dioxide (CO2), around 25-30%), varying quantities of Water (H2O) and Hydrogen Sulphide (H2S). Other compounds can also be found, especially in waste dump biogas: Ammonia (NH3), Hydrogen (H2), Nitrogen (N2) and Carbon Monoxide (CO). Methane is the valuable component under the aspect of using biogas fuel.

questions.Question: The major constituent of gobar gas is
questions.solution: Solution:		Biogas mainly comprises of three main gases. It is a mixture of methane, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide.

questions.Question: ________ is a by product of sewage treatment and can be decomposed to produce biogas
questions.solution: Solution:		Sludge is a by product of sewage treatment and can be decomposed to produce biogas.

questions.Question: Synthetic detergents are made from
questions.optionB: Sodium salt of benzene sulphonic acid
questions.optionC: Sodium salt of benzene carboxylic acid
questions.solution: Solution:		Synthetic detergents are made from sodium salt of benezene sulphonic acid.

questions.Question: Commonly used antiseptic 'Dettol' is a mixture of
questions.solution: Solution:		Commonly used antiseptic, dettol is a mixture of chloroxylenol and terpineol.

questions.Question: The gas used in the artificial ripening of fruits is
questions.solution: Solution:		Ethylene gas, acetylene gas liberated from calcium carbide, and ethephon are some of the commercial ripening agents used successfully in the trade and they have been widely studied for their effectiveness on initiating and accelerating the ripening process and their effect on fruit quality and health related issues.

questions.Question: The common refrigerant in domestic refrigerator is
questions.solution: Solution:		Common refrigerants used in domestic refrigerators are freon, neon and nitrogen. It flows through four components of refrigerator again and again. These four components are cooling chamber, compressor, heat exchanger and expander.

questions.Question: The chemical used in embalming biological materials is
questions.solution: Solution:		Embalming fluids use formaldehyde as a preservative. Formaldehyde is the simplest aldehyde with the chemical formula HCHO. Formalin is a solution of formaldehyde in water, usually with a small amount of methanol added. It is widely used as an antiseptic, disinfectant and preservative for biological materials.

questions.Question: Terylene is a condensation polymer of ethylene glycol and which acid?
questions.solution: Solution:		Terylene is a condensation polymer of ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid and also called polyester.

questions.Question: The material known in commerce as Terylene is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Terylene is the name for a synthetic polyester fibre. It is a synthetic polyester fibre or fabric based on terephthalic acid, characterized by lightness and crease resistance and used for clothing, sheets, ropes, sails, etc.

questions.Question: Nylon is a type of
questions.solution: Solution:		Nylon is a generic designation for a family of synthetic polymers, based on aliphatic or semi-aromatic polyamides. Nylon is a thermoplastic silky material that can be melt-processed into fibers, films, or shapes. It is made of repeating units linked by amide links similar to the peptide bonds in proteins.

questions.Question: Nylon is made up of :
questions.solution: Solution:		Nylon is a generic designation for a family of synthetic polymers, based on aliphatic or semi-aromatic polyamides. Nylon is a thermoplastic silky material that can be melt-processed into fibers, films, or shapes. It is made of repeating units linked by amide links similar to the peptide bonds in proteins.

questions.Question: Nylon threads are made of
questions.solution: Solution:		Nylon threads are polyamides. They are the condensation polymers of diamines and dibasic acids.

questions.Question: Which one of the following contributes largely to the ‘green house effect’ ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The primary greenhouse gases in the Earth's atmosphere are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone. When these gases are ranked by their direct contribution to the greenhouse effect in percentage terms, the most important are: Water vapour: 36-72 per cent; Carbon dioxide: 9-26 per cent; Methane: 4-9 per cent; and Ozone: 3-7 per cent.

questions.Question: An important green-house gas other than methane being produced from the agricultural fields is
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrous oxide is produced by combustion of fossil fuels, livestock wastes, breakdown of nitrogenous fertilizers in soil, nitrate contaminated water, nylon production and other industrial processes.

questions.Question: The gas which is mainly responsible for the green house effect is:
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary greenhouse gas emitted through human activities.

questions.Question: Chernobyl disaster is the result of pollution by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Chernobyl accident in 1986 was the result of a flawed reactor design that was operated with inadequately trained personnel. The resulting steam explosion and fires released at least 5% of the radioactive reactor core into the environment, with the deposition of radioactive materials in many parts of Europe.

questions.Question: ‘Aerosol’ is known as
questions.optionD: Green house gas present in air
questions.solution: Solution:		An aerosol (abbreviation of "aero-solution") is a suspension of fine solid particles or liquid droplets in air or another gas.

questions.Question: The human body is made up of several chemical elements; the element present in the highest proportion (65%) in the body is
questions.solution: Solution:		The human body is made up of several chemical elements; the element present in the highest proportion (65%) in the body is Oxygen.

questions.Question: The isomerism which exists between CH3CHCI2 and CH2CI. CH2CI is
questions.solution: Solution:		The isomerism which exists between CH3CHCI2 and CH2CI. CH2CI is positional isomerism.

questions.Question: The half life period of an isotope is 2 hours. After 6 hours what fraction of the initial quantity of the isotope will be left behind?
questions.solution: Solution:		The half life period of an isotope is 2 hours. After 6 hours 1/8 of the original amount, or 12.5% of the isotope will be left behind.

questions.Question: The number of waves made by an electron moving in an orbit having maximum magnetic quantum number is +3
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of waves made by an electron moving in an orbit having maximum magnetic quantum number is +3 is 4.

questions.Question: The number of atoms present in 21.6 gram of silver (atomic weight = 108) are same as the molecules in
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of atoms present in 21.6 gram of silver (atomic weight = 108) are same as the molecules in 12 moles of KMnO4.

questions.Question: Mercury is a :
questions.solution: Solution:		Mercury is a liquid metal.

questions.Question: The lustre of the metals is because of
questions.optionA: High density, due to closed packing of atoms
questions.optionC: Reflection of light due to the presence of free electrons
questions.optionD: Absorption of light due to the presence of cavities
questions.solution: Solution:		Lustre (or luster) is the way light interacts with the surface of a crystal, rock, or mineral. The word traces its origins back to the latin lux, meaning “light”, and generally implies radiance, gloss, or brilliance. Metals in general have high electrical conductivity, high thermal conductivity, and high density. Typically they are malleable and ductile, deforming under stress without cleaving. In terms of optical properties, metals are shiny and lustrous. Sheets of metal beyond a few micrometres in thickness appear opaque, but gold leaf transmits green light. Metallic (or splendant) minerals have the lustre of polished metal, and with ideal surfaces will work as a reflective surface. Examples include galena, pyrite and magnetite.

questions.Question: The non-metal found in the liquid state is
questions.solution: Solution:		The non-metal found in the liquid state is bromine.

questions.Question: Which among the following is liquid non-metal ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bromine is a liquid non-metal.

questions.Question: Metal are good conductors, because
questions.optionB: The molecules in them are very close to each other
questions.optionC: The molecules in them collide very freely
questions.solution: Solution:		Metals are an excellent conductor of electricity and heat because the atoms in the metals form a matrix through which outer electrons can move freely. Instead of orbiting their respective atoms, they form a sea of electrons that surround the positive nuclei of the interacting metal ions.

questions.Question: The increasing abundance of green house gases in atmosphere has led to the following effect except
questions.optionB: Depletion of ozone layer in the stratosphere
questions.solution: Solution:		The increasing abundance of green house gases in atmosphere has led to the following effect except oxygen fertilization effect.

questions.Question: The source of energy that causes the least global warming is
questions.solution: Solution:		Fossil fuels — coal, petroleum, and natural gas — are the primary culprit behind climate change. They contribute more than 80 percent of greenhouse gas emissions — and 98 percent of CO2 emissions alone. On the contrary, Geothermal energy is thermal energy generated and stored in the Earth. It is clean and sustainable.

questions.Question: Which of the following fuels causes minimum environmental pollution?
questions.solution: Solution:		When hydrogen burns it becomes water vapor. There are no carbon or other compounds released into the atmosphere. There are various compounds including carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide released when other fuels are burnt.

questions.Question: Biofertilizers convert nitrogen to ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Bio-fertilizers are micro-organisms which bring about nutrient enrichment of soil by enhancing the availability of nutrients to crops. The micro-organisms which act as bio-fertilizers are bacteria, cyanobacteria (blue green algae) and mycorrhizal fungi. The symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria convert free nitrogen to ammonia, which the host plant utilizes for its development.

questions.Question: The elements in the modern Periodic table are arranged according to their
questions.solution: Solution:		The elements in the modern periodic table are arranged according to their atomic number.

questions.Question: A fertile soil is likely to have a pH of
questions.solution: Solution:		A fertile soil is likely to have a pH of 6-7.

questions.Question: Litmus is obtained from
questions.solution: Solution:		Litmus, mixture of coloured organic compounds obtained from several species of lichens that grow in the Netherlands, particularly Lecanora tartarea and Roccella tinctorum.

questions.Question: The pH of lemon juice is expected to be
questions.solution: Solution:		The pH level of lemon juice is, 2.00 to 2.60. It varies depending on the lemon. pH expresses different levels of acidity or alkalinity within a solution.

questions.Question: Antacids are found in drugs that give relief to
questions.solution: Solution:		Antacids are found in drugs that give relief to stomach ache.

questions.Question: The pH of human blood is between
questions.solution: Solution:		The pH of human blood is between 7.5-8.

questions.Question: A powerful eye irritant present in smog is
questions.solution: Solution:		Peroxyacetyl nitrate is a secondary pollutant present in photochemical smog. It is thermally unstable and decomposes into peroxyethanoyl radicals and nitrogen dioxide gas. It is a lachrymatory substance.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a natural source of air pollution ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Natural pollution comes from natural sources like release of methane by cattle and paddy fields, carbon dioxide from plants and animals, dust storms, nitrogen oxides, ozone, volcanic eruptions, emission of natural gas, sol erosion, ultraviolet rays,etc. Mercury is not a cause of natural pollution.

questions.Question: CNG used in automobiles to check pollution, mainly consists of
questions.solution: Solution:		Nature gas is 95 percent Methane (CH4) plus four other hydrocarbons: Ethane (C2H6) - 2.5 %, Propane (C3H8) - 0.2 %, Butane (C4H10) - 0.06%, Pentanes Plus (C5H12 + C10H22) -0.02%. It also contains small amounts of: Nitrogen (N2) - 1.6%, Carbon Dixoide (CO2) - 0.7%, Hydrogen Sulphide (H2S) - trace, Water (H2O) - trace.

questions.Question: What are the major pollutants of cigarette smoke?
questions.solution: Solution:		Particulate matter consists of millions of tiny particles of diverse chemical composition. Particulate matter from tobacco smoke includes many particles in the size range that reflects light, which explains why tobacco smoke is easily seen by the eye. In contrast to smoke particles, gases emitted by the cigarette such as benzene and carbon monoxide (CO) are invisible to the eye. Particles smaller than 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5) are major components of cigarette smoke and can enter deep into the lung where they can cause serious health problems. The pollutants generated by the cigarette arise from the chemical process of burning organic matter, or combustion of tobacco and paper. Combustion processes, such as wood burning or waste incineration, emit thousands of pollutants, some of which are in the gas phase and some of which are in the form of small particles called particulate matter.

questions.Question: Which of the following metals is not a pollutant ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Aluminium is not a pollutant.

questions.Question: The purest form of Iron is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Wrought iron is purest form of iron.

questions.Question: Which one of the following contains maximum percentage of carbon ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cast iron has the maximum percentage of carbon.

questions.Question: Stainless steel is an alloy of
questions.solution: Solution:		Stainless steel is an alloy of chromium, carbon and iron.

questions.Question: Iron is extracted from
questions.solution: Solution:		Iron is extracted from Haematite.

questions.Question: Which is the purest form of iron?
questions.solution: Solution:		Wrought iron is purest form of iron. It contain 99.5% iron, 0.25% carbon and 0.25% other impurities of S, P, Si etc.

questions.Question: The gas produced in marshy places due to decomposition of vegetation is
questions.solution: Solution:		Methane gas is a hydrocarbon gas largely composed of methane formed when organic material or vegetation decays in the absence of air. Naturally occurring methane is mainly produced by the process of methanogenesis. It is also known as Swamp Gas.

questions.Question: Organic compounds are
questions.solution: Solution:		Organic compounds are covalent compounds.

questions.Question: Vinegar is an aqueous solution of
questions.solution: Solution:		Vinegar is an aqueous solution of acetic acid and trace chemicals that may include flavorings. Vinegar typically contains 5–8% acetic acid by volume.

questions.Question: Two elements which can form a large number of compounds are
questions.solution: Solution:		The carbon-hydrogen bond (C-H bond) is a bond between carbon and hydrogen atoms that can be found in many organic compounds. Compound classes consisting solely of C-H bonds and C-C bonds are alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, and aromatic hydrocarbons. Collectively they are known as hydrocarbons.

questions.Question: Alcoholic (– OH) group can be identified by :
questions.solution: Solution:		As phenol is an aromatic alcohol, so FeCl3 test is a test for alcohol and esterificaton test is also a test for alcohol. The ferric chloride test is used to determine the presence or absence of phenols in a given sample (for instance natural phenols in a plant extract).

questions.Question: Which substance is used to retard the setting action of cement?
questions.solution: Solution:		CaSO4.2H2O (Gypsum) is added to cement clinker to retard setting action of cement.

questions.Question: Stalactites and Stalagmites form due to the precipitation of :
questions.solution: Solution:		Stalactites and stalagmites are formed by water dripping or flowing from fractures on the ceiling of a cave. The dominant mineral in them is calcite (calcium carbonate) or CaCaO3. Their largest displays are formed in caves of limestone and dolomite. Other minerals that may be deposited include other carbonates, opal, chalcedony, limonite, and some sulfides.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a precious/semi-precious stone?
questions.solution: Solution:		A pearl is a hard object produced within the soft tissue (specifically the mantle) of a living shelled mollusk. Just like the shell of a clam, a pearl is made up of calcium carbonate in minute crystalline form, which has been deposited in concentric layers. The ideal pearl is perfectly round and smooth, but many other shapes of pearls (baroque pearls) occur. The finest quality natural pearls have been highly valued as gemstones and objects of beauty for many centuries, and because of this, the word pearl has become a metaphor for something very rare, fine, admirable, and valuable.

questions.Question: The chemical substance present in bones and teeth is
questions.solution: Solution:		Seventy percent of bone consists of hydroxyapatite, a calcium phosphate mineral (known as bone mineral). Tooth enamel is composed of almost ninety percent hydroxylapatite.

questions.Question: The chemical substance present in bones and teeth is
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: The metal does not give H2 on treatment with dilute HCL is
questions.solution: Solution:		The metal does not give H2 on treatment with dilute HCL is Ag.

questions.Question: The number of g-molecule of oxygen in 6.02 x 1024 CO molecules is
questions.solution: Solution:		In this question gram molecules simply means number of moles of O2 molecules. So we have 6.02*10^24 atoms of Oxygen means 3.01*10^24 molecules of O2. 3.01*10^24 molecules of O2 are equal to 5 moles. Source : Quora.com

questions.Question: The most extensive, commercially useful source of thorium as monazite sand occurs in India at
questions.solution: Solution:		The most extensive, commercially useful source of thorium as monazite sand occurs in India at Travancore coast.

questions.Question: The main active constituent of tea and coffee is
questions.solution: Solution:		Caffeine is the main active constituent of tea and coffee.

questions.Question: The maximum number of isomers for an alkene with molecular formula C4H8 is
questions.solution: Solution:		The maximum number of isomers for an alkene with molecular formula C4H8 is 4.

questions.Question: Maximum permissible concentration of copper in drinking water in mg/L is
questions.solution: Solution:		The 1959 WHO International Standards for Drinking Water suggested that concentrations of copper greater than 1.5 mg/litre would markedly impair the potability of the water. However, in the first edition of the Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, published in 1984, a guideline value of 1.0 mg/litre was established for copper, based on its laundry and other staining properties.

questions.Question: The amount of chlorine available in water after disinfection is called as
questions.solution: Solution:		The word “residual” means “remainder” or “that which is left”, and as the name suggests the chlorine residual is measure of the amount of chlorine remaining in the water after disinfection. The chlorine residual is usually tested in finished water which is ready to be released into the distribution system, although operators must also ensure that there is adequate residual at the extreme ends of the distribution system. Tests for chlorine residual are probably the most frequently performed tests at water treatment plants. There are three types of chlorine residual which must be considered in water treatment. Free chlorine residual - residual consisting of dissolved chlorine gas, Hypochlorous acid, and hypochlorite ions, Combined chlorine residual - residual consisting of other forms of chlorine such as chloramines which are capable of killing bacteria and oxidizing organic matter, Total chlorine residual - the sum of the free chlorine residual and the combined chlorine residual.

questions.Question: Maximum permissible concentration of total hardness in drinking water is
questions.solution: Solution:		Maximum permissible concentration of total hardness in drinking water is 200.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is extensively used for sterilizing water ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bleaching powder is extensively used in sterilizing water. Calcium hypochlorite is a chemical compound with formula Ca(OCl)2. It is widely used for water treatment and as a bleaching agent (bleaching powder). This chemical is considered to be relatively stable and has greater available chlorine than sodium hypochlorite (liquid bleach). Calcium hypochlorite is a yellow white solid which has a strong smell of chlorine. It is not highly soluble in water, and is more preferably used in soft to medium-hard water. It has two forms: a dry form and a hydrated form. The hydrated form is safer to handle.

questions.Question: Assertion (A) : Synthetic detergents can lather when in hard water.Reason (R) : Synthetic detergents form soluble calcium and magnesium salts with hard water.
questions.optionA: Both A and R is true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.optionB: Both A and R is true but R is not a correct explanation of A
questions.optionC: A is true but R is false
questions.optionD: A is false but R is true
questions.solution: Solution:		Both A and R is true and R is the correct explanation of A.

questions.Question: Copper substances when exposed to air gains a green coating due to the formation of:
questions.solution: Solution:		When copper is exposed to air, it reacts with moist carbon dioxide in the air and slowly loses its shiny brown surface and gains a green coat. This green substance is basic copper carbonate (CuCO3. Cu (OH)2). The formation of this green coating on the surface of a copper object corrodes it.

questions.Question: Browning of paper in old books is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Foxing is a term describing the age-related spots and browning seen on vintage paper documents such as books, postage stamps, certificates, and so forth. It results from localized accelerated oxidation of cellulose or the effect on certain papers of the oxidation of iron, copper, etc.

questions.Question: Catalyst is a substance which
questions.optionA: Increases the rate of the reaction
questions.optionC: Has no action on the rate of the reaction
questions.solution: Solution:		Catalyst, in chemistry, any substance that increases the rate of a reaction without itself being consumed.

questions.Question: When quick lime is added to water
questions.solution: Solution:		The quick lime reaction with water is exothermic in nature due to production of heat. The slaked lime creates a suspension in water since it is only slightly soluble in water. The clear solution formed after the slaked lime gets settled is also known as lime water.

questions.Question: What is the element that is in the highest percentage in the composition of the earth ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen has the highest percentage in both human body and on earth, but carbon, the element with the second highest percentage in the body, is relatively rare on Earth.

questions.Question: An alloy used in making heating elements for electric heating device is
questions.solution: Solution:		An alloy used in making heating elements for electric heating devices is nichrome. It is an alloy of nickel, chromium, (and sometimes iron and other elements or substances). It is used as resistance wire.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an iron ore ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Magnetite is an iron ore.

questions.Question: The important metal used with iron to produce stainless steel is
questions.solution: Solution:		Stainless steels are iron alloys with a minimum of 10.5% chromium. Other alloying elements are added to enhance their structure and properties such as formability, strength and cryogenic toughness. These include metals such as: Nickel.

questions.Question: Which of the following metals form an amalgam with other metals ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mercury form an amalgam with other metals.

questions.Question: ________ gives hardness to stainless steel.
questions.solution: Solution:		Iron is alloyed with carbon lo make steel and has the effect of increasing the hardness and strength of iron. Pure iron cannot be hardened or strengthened by heat treatment but the addition of carbon enables a wide range of hardness and strength. High-carbon stainless steel contains a minimum of 0.3% carbon. The higher the carbon content, the less formable and the tougher the steel becomes.

questions.Question: Synthetic detergents are prepared from
questions.solution: Solution:		Synthetic detergents are prepared from hydrocarbons of petroleum. They are sodium salts of a long chain benzene sulphonic acids or sodium salts of long chain alkyl hydrogen sulphates. Calcium and magnesium salts of detergents are soluble in water. Therefore cleansing action of detergents remain unaffected in hard water.

questions.Question: What is a mixture of potassium nitrate, powdered charcoal and sulphur called?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gun powder is the mixture of potassium nitrate powdered charcoal and sulphur.

questions.Question: Iodex, a pain relief balm, has the smell of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Iodex has the characteristic odour of Methyl salicylate, an organic ester naturally produced by many species of plants, particularly wintergreens. It is used in high concentrations as a rubefacient and analgesic in deep heating liniments to treat joint and muscular pain.

questions.Question: Silver halides are used in photographic plates because they are
questions.solution: Solution:		Silver halides are used in photography because they are photosensitive as they react with light to form the image, silver halides being reduced to silver. They are also soluble in hyposolution.

questions.Question: Who developed Hydrogen Bomb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Edward Teller, Stanislaw M. Ulam, and other American scientists developed the first hydrogen bomb, which was tested at Enewetak atoll on November 1, 1952.

questions.Question: The main use of salt in the diet is to
questions.optionA: make the taste of food better
questions.optionB: produce in small amounts the hydrochloric acid required for the digestion of food
questions.optionD: increase the solubility of food particles in water
questions.solution: Solution:		The main use of salt in the diet is to produce in small amounts the hydrochloric acid required for the digestion of food.

questions.Question: The monomer of polythene is
questions.solution: Solution:		Polyethylene is the most common plastic. The monomer is ethylene, a gaseous hydrocarbon with the formula C2H4 which can be viewed as a pair of methylene groups connected to each other.

questions.Question: The luster of a metal is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Metallic lustre is due to the mobile electrons present in metals which when de-excites releases energy in the form of light.

questions.Question: The number of water molecules present in a drop of water (volume 0.0018 ml) at room temperature is
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of water molecules present in a drop of water (volume 0.0018 ml) at room temperature is 6.023 x 1019.

questions.Question: The most malleable metal is
questions.solution: Solution:		The most malleable metal is gold.

questions.Question: Which of the following is very reactive and kept in kerosene?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium is a very reactive metal. It reacts vigorously with oxygen and water. A lot of heat is generated in this process. Therefore, it is stored in kerosene to avoid contacts between either atmospheric oxygen or water.

questions.Question: Which metal does not undergo corrosion due to the formation of oxide layer?
questions.solution: Solution:		Corrosion is an oxidation reaction with atmospheric oxygen in the presence of water on the surface of a metal. Iron corrodes more quickly than most other transition metals to form an iron oxide. Aluminium also undergoes an oxidation reaction, but does not oxidize and corrode as quickly as its reactivity suggests. Once a thin oxide layer of Al2O3 has formed on the surface, it forms a barrier to oxygen and water to prevent further corrosion of the aluminium.

questions.Question: The wire of flash bulb is made of:
questions.solution: Solution:		The first modern photoflash bulb (or flashbulb) was made by Austrian Paul Vierkotter, who used magnesium coated wire in an evacuated glass globe. It was later determined that aluminum foil in a low pressure oxygen atmosphere worked even better, and was cheaper to produce.

questions.Question: Identify the metal which is non toxic in nature.
questions.solution: Solution:		Toxic metals are metals that form poisonous soluble compounds and have no biological role, i.e. are not essential minerals, or are in the wrong form. Most often the definition includes at least cadmium, lead, mercury and the radioactive metals. Metals in an oxidation state abnormal to the body may also become toxic: chromium (III) is an essential trace element, but chromium(VI) is a carcinogen. Similarly, cobalt could also be toxic.

questions.Question: Iron rusts quickly in
questions.solution: Solution:		Water is the enabler of fast oxidation of iron. So freshwater will also cause rust. However, salt water (sea water) is a very good conductor (lots of dissociated ions) and so there are a number of electrolysis reactions that tremendously accelerate corrosion in salt water. This effect can be reversed by using a metal (like zinc) which causes the current to be reversed and in effect the zinc corrodes rapidly, protecting the iron.

questions.Question: The constituents of automobile exhaust that can cause cancer is/are :
questions.solution: Solution:		Lead is a naturally occurring bluish-gray metal found in small amounts in the earth’s crust. In the past, when lead was added to gasoline, breathing automobile exhaust was the major source of lead exposure for most people. Lead in the exhaust also contaminated the soil near roads. Another major source of exposure is old paint that contains lead. Lead has been found to be carcinogen. A substance that causes cancer or helps cancer grow is called a carcinogen. Several studies have looked for a link between exposure to lead in the workplace (mainly among battery workers and smelter workers) and lung cancer. Some of these studies have found a small increase in lung cancer risk. Studies have also looked at possible links between workplace exposures to lead and other cancers, including cancers of the brain, kidney, bladder, colon, and rectum.

questions.Question: The acid rain destroys vegetations because it contains
questions.solution: Solution:		Acid rain is a formed due to the mixing of oxides of several harmful gases with the rain. Acid rain formation result from both natural sources, such as volcanoes and decaying vegetation, and man-made sources, primarily emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides resulting from fossil fuel combustion. These gases react in the atmosphere with water, oxygen, and other chemicals to form various acidic compounds.When this rain falls on the soil, the soil becomes acidic. Also, the leaves get destroyed and germinating seeds get corroded. Plants experience stunted growth. Thus, vegetation is destroyed. So, the correct answer is option D.

questions.Question: Of the following, which one pollutes the air of a big city ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lead pollution primarily came from cars in the past. Today, lead pollution primarily comes from lead smelters, metal processing plants and incinerators. Deposits of lead in soil can harm both humans and animals by absorbing it into a body.

questions.Question: Of the following which one pollutes the air of a big city ?
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Which of the following is usually not an air-pollutant?
questions.solution: Solution:		The six air pollutants are carbon monoxide, lead, ground-level ozone, nitrogen dioxide, particulate matter, and sulfur dioxide.The combustion of gasoline and other hydrocarbon fuels in automobiles, trucks, and jet airplanes produces several primary air pollutants. Nitrous oxide (N2O), commonly known as laughing gas, is used in surgery and dentistry for its anaesthetic and analgesic effects.

questions.Question: Sour taste of lemon is due to the presence of which of the following ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lemon juice is about 5% citric acid, which gives lemons a sour taste and a pH of 2 to 3. Citric acid is found in many fruits but lemon contains large quantity of citric acid. The distinctive sour taste of lemon juice makes it a key ingredient in drinks and foods such as lemonade and lemon meringue pie.

questions.Question: pH scale ranges from
questions.solution: Solution:		pH is a measure of how acidic/basic water is. The range goes from 0 - 14, with 7 being neutral.

questions.Question: Normal rainwater has a pH level of
questions.solution: Solution:		Normal rainwater has a pH level of 5.6.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is used as preservative for foodstuff ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium benzoate is a preservative. It is bacteriostatic and fungistatic under acidic conditions. It is most widely used in acidic foods such as salad dressings (vinegar), carbonated drinks (carbonic acid), jams and fruit juices (citric acid), pickles (vinegar), and condiments. It is also used as a preservative in medicines and cosmetics.

questions.Question: The acid which fails to liberate carbon dioxide from sodium bicarbonate is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium bicarbonate and organic acid (Formic acid, Acetic acid, Carbonic acid, etc) react vigorously to liberate carbon dioxide. For example, Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) when treated with acetic acid reacts vigorously to liberate carbon dioxide.

questions.Question: What is the atomic number of mercury?
questions.solution: Solution:		The atomic number of mercury is 80.

questions.Question: Which of the following molecules has a bond order of 2.5?
questions.solution: Solution:		F2 has a bond order of 2.5.

questions.Question: An element of atomic no. 29 belongs to
questions.solution: Solution:		Copper (Cu) has the atomic number of 29. Copper belongs to the d-block which is the collective name for Groups 3 to 12 in the periodic table. Most of the d-block elements are considered to be metals, with a common lustrous metallic appearance.

questions.Question: Which metal is the heaviest in periodic table among the following ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Osmium is the heaviest element of all (22.61g per cubic centimetre).

questions.Question: Ruby and sapphire are oxides of
questions.solution: Solution:		Aluminium forms one stable oxide, known by its mineral name corundum. Sapphire and ruby are impure corundum contaminated with trace amounts of other metals. Corundum is a crystalline form of aluminium oxide (Al2O3) with traces of iron, titanium and chromium. It is a rock-forming mineral. It is one of the naturally clear transparent materials, but can have different colours when impurities are present. Transparent specimens are used as gems, called ruby if red and padparadscha if pink-orange. All other colours are called sapphire, e.g., “green sapphire” for a green specimen. Because of corundum’s hardness (pure corundum is defined to have 9.0 Mohs), it can scratch almost every other mineral. It is commonly used as an abrasive, on everything from sandpaper to large machines used in machining metals, plastics, and wood. Some emery is a mix of corundum and other substances, and the mix is less abrasive, with an average hardness near 8.0.

questions.Question: Which one of the following mineral does not contain oxygen ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cryolite (Na3AlF6, sodium hexafluoroaluminate) does not contain oxygen. It occurs as glassy, colorless, white-reddish to gray-black prismatic monoclinic crystals. Cryolite is used as an insecticide and a pesticide. It is also used to give fireworks a yellow color.

questions.Question: Which mineral is the ore of aluminium ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Of all the aluminium ores, bauxite is the chief ore of aluminium.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a metallic ore ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Galena is the most abundant lead mineral. It is a metallic, lead-gray mineral with cubic cleavage and a distinctly high density. It belongs to the octahedral sulfide group of minerals with metal ions in octahedral positions.

questions.Question: Magnalium is an alloy of
questions.solution: Solution:		Magnalium is an aluminium alloy with 1.5 to 2% magnesium and small amounts of copper, nickel, and tin. Some alloys, intended for particular uses at the cost of poor corrosion resistance, may consist of up to 50% magnesium. It finds use in engineering and pyrotechnics. Alloys with smaller amounts of magnesium (about 5%) exhibit greater strength, greater corrosion resistance, and lower density than pure aluminium. Such alloys are also more workable and easier to weld than pure aluminium. Alloys with high amounts of magnesium (around 50%) are brittle and more susceptible to corrosion than aluminium. Although they are generally more expensive than aluminium, the high strength, low density, and greater workability of alloys with low amounts of magnesium leads to their use in aircraft and automobile parts.

questions.Question: Magnetite is
questions.solution: Solution:		Magnetite is a rock mineral and one of the main iron ores, with the chemical formula Fe₃O₄.

questions.Question: L.P.G. is mostly liquefied
questions.solution: Solution:		L.P.G. is mostly liquefied butane.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not coal variety?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dolomite is not coal variety.

questions.Question: Which of the following is used to increase the anti-knocking property of petrol ?
questions.solution: Solution:		An anti-knocking agent is the substance which is used to reduce the engine knocking. It increases the octane number of the fuel. It helps in auto-ignition by raising the temperature and pressure. TEL is tetraethyl Lead which is used as an anti-knocking compound.

questions.Question: The quality of petrol is expressed in terms of
questions.solution: Solution:		Ignition quality of petrol is expressed by octane number and that of diesel by cetane number.

questions.Question: Which of the following type of coal has the lowest proportion of volatile matter ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Anthracite has the lowest proportion of volatile matter.

questions.Question: What is the chemical symbol of mercury?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hg is the chemical symbol of mercury.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a monoatomic gas?
questions.solution: Solution:		Neon is a monoatomic gas among the following.

questions.Question: The purest form of water in nature is
questions.solution: Solution:		Rain water is considered the purest form of water. Impurities and salts present in water on earth are left behind during vaporisation by the sun.

questions.Question: In drinking water supply, which of the following treatments is not involved
questions.solution: Solution:		Softening is not involved in drinking water supply.

questions.Question: The two metal ions that cause hardness to water are:
questions.solution: Solution:		Calcium and magnesium ion cause hardness of water.

questions.Question: Entropy of Universe is always
questions.solution: Solution:		The second law of thermodynamics can be stated in terms of entropy. In an irreversible process, entropy always increases, so the change in entropy is positive. The total entropy of the universe is continually increasing. There is a strong connection between probability and entropy.

questions.Question: In a reaction of the type A+B -> C+D one could ensure it to be a first order reaction by :
questions.optionB: Increasing the concentration of a product
questions.optionC: Increasing the concentration of a reactant
questions.solution: Solution:		In a reaction of the type A+B -> C+D one could ensure it to be a first order reaction by increasing the concentration of a reactant.

questions.Question: Kinetics is the study of:
questions.optionC: The mechanisms and paths of the molecules take in joining from one reactant to products
questions.solution: Solution:		In physics and engineering, kinetics is the branch of classical mechanics that is concerned with the relationship between motion and its causes, specifically, forces and torques. The term kinetics is also used to refer to chemical kinetics, particularly in chemical physics and physical chemistry.

questions.Question: Bhopal gas tragedy is associated with leakage of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Bhopal disaster, also referred to as the Bhopal gas tragedy, was a gas leak incident in India, considered one of the world’s worst industrial disasters. It occurred on the night of 2–3 December, 1984 at the Union Carbide India Limited (UCIL) pesticide plant in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. Over 500,000 people were exposed to methyl isocyanate gas and other chemicals. The toxic substance made its way in and around the shantytowns located near the plant. Estimates vary on the death toll. The official immediate death toll was 2,259. The government of Madhya Pradesh confirmed a total of 3,787 deaths related to the gas release. Others estimate 8,000 died within two weeks and another 8,000 or more have since died from gas-related diseases.

questions.Question: The function of sedimentation tank in sewage treatment is to:
questions.solution: Solution:		A sedimentation tank allows suspended particles to settle out of water or wastewater as it flows slowly through the tank, thereby providing some degree of purification. A layer of accumulated solids, called sludge, forms at the bottom of the tank and is periodically removed.

questions.Question: Which one of the following forms of phosphorus is most reactive?
questions.solution: Solution:		The white phosphorus allotrope is the most reactive, least stable and most toxic of the three. It consists of four phosphorus molecules that chemically bond to form a tetrahedral shape.

questions.Question: Limestone is a raw material used by which industry?
questions.solution: Solution:		Limestone is used as a raw-material for the manufacture of quicklime (calcium oxide), slaked lime (calcium hydroxide), cement and mortar. Clay and shale are also used as raw materials for the production of cement.

questions.Question: The element absorbed both in cation and anion form is
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen, required in large quantities for healthy plant growth, is supplied either as a cation (ammonium - NH4+) or an anion (nitrate - NO3-). The ratio of these two forms of nitrogen in the nutrient solution can have large effects on both the rate and direction of pH changes with time.

questions.Question: Cement containing excess amount of lime
questions.solution: Solution:		In cement almost entire amount of lime is present in combined state as calcium silicates and calcium aluminates. Cement containing excess amount of lime cracks during setting while cement containing less amount of lime is weak in strength. Setting of cement is an exothermic process.

questions.Question: Commercially, sodium bicarbonate is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium bicarbonate commonly known as baking soda, is a chemical compound with the formula NaHCO3.

questions.Question: Brass is made of
questions.solution: Solution:		Brass is a homogeneous mixture (solid solution) of copper and zinc.

questions.Question: Bridgmanite is
questions.optionA: A bridge on the river Thames
questions.solution: Solution:		Bridgmanite is earth's most abundant mineral.

questions.Question: Bronze is an alloy of
questions.solution: Solution:		Bronze is an alloy traditionally composed of copper and tin.

questions.Question: Percentage of carbon in steel ranges from
questions.solution: Solution:		Steel is an alloy made by combining iron and other elements, the most common of these being carbon. When carbon is used, its content in the steel is between 0.2% and 2.1% by weight, depending on the grade. Other alloying elements sometimes used are manganese, chromium, vanadium and tungsten. Carbon and other elements act as a hardening agent, preventing dislocations in the iron atom crystal lattice from sliding past one another. Varying the amount of alloying elements and the form of their presence in the steel (solute elements, precipitated phase) controls qualities such as the hardness, ductility, and tensile strength of the resulting steel. Steel with increased carbon content can be made harder and stronger than iron, but such steel is also less ductile than iron. Alloys with a higher than 2.1% carbon content are known as cast iron because of their lower melting point and good castability.

questions.Question: Copper is refined by
questions.solution: Solution:		Copper is refined by roasting.

questions.Question: Which one is a soluble salt in H2O?
questions.solution: Solution:		CaCl2 is a soluble salt in H2O.

questions.Question: Vinegar is ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Vinegar is diluted formic acid.

questions.Question: pH value between 6.5-7.5 makes the soil
questions.solution: Solution:		pH value between 6.5-7.5 makes the soil neutral.

questions.Question: A pungent smell often present near the urinals is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		A pungent smell often present near the urinals is due to ammonia.

questions.Question: Ammonial is a mixture of
questions.solution: Solution:		Ammonial is an explosive made up of ammonium nitrate and aluminium powder. The ammonium nitrate functions as an oxidizer and the aluminium as fuel. The use of the relatively cheap ammonium nitrate and aluminium makes it a replacement for pure TNT. The mixture is affected by humidity because ammonium nitrate is highly hygroscopic. Ammonal is not easily detonated, requiring a fairly substantial shock, though it is still more sensitive than trinitrotoluene and composition C4 . The detonation velocity of ammonal is approximately 4,400 metres per second or 9,842 miles per hour. Ammonal used for military mining purposes was generally contained within metal cans or rubberised bags to prevent moisture ingress problems. The composition of ammonal used at Messines was 65% ammonium nitrate, 17% aluminum, 15% trinitrotoluene (TNT) and 3% charcoal. Ammonal remains in use as an industrial explosive. Typically, it is used for quarrying or mining purposes.

questions.Question: Which of the following elements is not present in stainless steel?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tungsten is not present in stainless steel.

questions.Question: Which one of the following minerals is found in pure form?
questions.solution: Solution:		Copper is one of very few elements that are found in essentially pure form in nature. But the bulk of the copper resource is found in other minerals.

questions.Question: What is the principal ore of aluminium ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bauxite is an aluminium ore and is the main source of aluminium. This form of rock consists mostly of the minerals gibbsite ,boehmite , and diaspore , in a mixture with the two iron oxides goethite and hematite, the clay mineral kaolinite, and small amounts of anatase TiO2. Bauxite was named after the village Les Baux in southern France, where it was first recognised as containing aluminium and named by the French geologist Pierre Berthier in 1821. Lateritic bauxites (silicate bauxites) are distinguished from karst bauxite ores (carbonate bauxites). The early discovered carbonate bauxites occur predominantly in Europe and Jamaica above carbonate rocks (limestone and dolomite), where they were formed by lateritic weathering and residual accumulation of intercalated clays or by clay dissolution residues of the limestone.

questions.Question: Burning pyrites ore gives out
questions.solution: Solution:		The mineral pyrite, or iron pyrite, is an iron sulfide with the formula FeS2. Pyrite remains in commercial use for the production of sulfur dioxide, for use in such applications as the paper industry, and in the manufacture of sulfuric acid.

questions.Question: Which one of the following pairs is not correctly matched?
questions.solution: Solution:		Haematite : Copper is not correctly matched.

questions.Question: Which type of radiations are absorbed by the upper layer of the atmosphere?
questions.solution: Solution:		The upper atmosphere derives most of its energy by direct absorption of solar electromagnetic energy in the ultraviolet and X-ray regions of the spectrum.

questions.Question: Sulphur dioxide level in the atmosphere can be reduced by using
questions.optionC: Static electricity to attract it in factory chimneys
questions.solution: Solution:		Sulphur dioxide level in the atmosphere can be reduced by using low sulphur fuels.

questions.Question: The term 'brown air' is used for
questions.solution: Solution:		Photochemical smog which is mainly composed of ozone (O3), Peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) and Nox, is also known as brown air where solar radiation is intense. In seasons of lesser solar radiation or areas, smog formation is incomplete and the air is referred to as grey air.

questions.Question: The sewage obtained from water closets and urinals is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The sewage obtained from water closets and urinals in known as Sanitary waste.

questions.Question: Which one amongst the following is not a Green House gas?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen is not a Green House gas.

questions.Question: Two moles of an ideal gas expand freely into vacuum. The work done by the gas is
questions.solution: Solution:		Two moles of an ideal gas expands spontaneously into vacuum, the work done is zero.

questions.Question: The Fungus which is used in the alcohol industry is
questions.solution: Solution:		Yeasts are the main fermentor and alcohol producer in the production of wine, beer and other alcohol drinks. The main yeast species used is Saccharomyces cerevisiae. It ferments the sugars, coming from different sources, e.g., grapes for wine, barley for beer, to alcohol and carbon dioxide.

questions.Question: Which of the following is used to denature ethanol ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Denatured alcohol is ethanol that has additives to make it undrinkable (poisonous), to discourage recreational consumption. Different additives are used to make it difficult to use distillation or other simple processes to reverse the denaturation. Methanol is commonly used both because its boiling point is close to that of ethanol and because it is toxic.

questions.Question: Ethanol containing 5% water is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A rectified alcohol is highly concentrated ethanol which has been purified by means of repeated distillation, a process that is called rectification. It typically contains 95% alcohol by volume and 5 % water. Normally, ethanol with 5 % water is known as pure alcohol.

questions.Question: Alcohol prepared by the distillation of wood is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Alcohol prepared by the distillation of wood is Methyl alcohol. It is also called wood spirit.

questions.Question: The main component of liquid bleach is:
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium hypochlorite bleaches are also called chlorine or liquid household bleach. They are the more powerful laundry bleaches; they are used to whiten and disinfect laundry, is typically either 5.25 percent (regular strength) or 6 percent sodium hypochlorite (ultra strength).

questions.Question: Quartz is made of
questions.solution: Solution:		Quartz is an abundant mineral in the Earth’s continental crust. It is made up of a continuous framework of SiO4 silicon–oxygen tetrahedra, with each oxygen being shared between two tetrahedra, giving an overall formula SiO2. There are many different varieties of quartz, several of which are semiprecious gemstones. Most quartz used in microelectronics is produced synthetically. Large, flawless and un-twinned crystals are produced in an autoclave via the hydrothermal process. The process involves treating crushed natural quartz with hot aqueous solution of a base such as sodium hydroxide.

questions.Question: What is the product formed when sodium bicarbonate is heated strongly?
questions.solution: Solution:		When sodium bicarbonate is strongly heated, it decomposes into sodium carbonate, water vapor, and carbon dioxide. Solid sodium carbonate is a white powder and is used in cooking under the name ‘baking powder’; sodium bicarbonate is used in baking under the name ‘baking soda’.

questions.Question: Cement is formed by strongly heating a mixture of
questions.solution: Solution:		Cement is made by heating limestone (calcium carbonate) with small quantities of other materials (such as clay) to 1450 degree C in a kiln, in a process known as calcination, whereby a molecule of carbon dioxide is liberated from the calcium carbonate to form calcium oxide, or quicklime, which is then blended with the other materials that have been included in the mix. The resulting hard substance, called ‘clinker’, is then ground with a small amount of gypsum into a powder to make ‘Ordinary Portland Cement’, the most commonly used type of cement (often referred to as OPC). Portland cement is a basic ingredient of concrete, mortar and most non-specialty grout. The most common use for Portland cement is in the production of concrete.

questions.Question: Persons working in cement plants and lime stone quarries are prone to disease like
questions.solution: Solution:		Silicosis is caused due to lung fibrosis caused by the inhalation of dust containing silica. Since the person is working in cement plants and limestone quarries and cement is made up of silica, lime, alumina etc. so, the person is most affected or prone to the disease known as Silicosis.

questions.Question: Which one of the following elements is an example of noble gas ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Helium is an example of noble gas.

questions.Question: Helium gas is filled in balloons because
questions.optionC: It is one of the constitutents of water
questions.solution: Solution:		Because of the Archimedes’ principle, a lifting gas is required for aerostats to create buoyancy. Its density is lower than that of air (about 1.29 kg/m3, 1.29 g/ L). Only certain lighter than air gases are suitable as lifting gases. Hydrogen and helium are the most commonly used lift gases. Although helium is twice as heavy as (diatomic) hydrogen, they are both so much lighter than air that this difference is inconsequential. Both provide about 9.8 N of lift (1 Newton is the force required to accelerate 1 kg at 1 m/sec2) per cubic meter of gas at STP. Helium is the second lightest gas. For that reason, it is an attractive gas for lifting as well. A major advantage is that this gas is noncombustible. Today helium is used instead of hydrogen, since it is inert so non-flammable which makes things a lot safer. Hydrogen can ignite very easily when mixed with the oxygen of the surrounding air.

questions.Question: The inert gas which is substituted for nitrogen in the air used by deep sea divers for breathing is
questions.solution: Solution:		Trimix is a mixture of oxygen, nitrogen and helium and is often used at depth in technical diving and commercial diving instead of air to reduce nitrogen narcosis and to avoid the dangers of oxygen toxicity.

questions.Question: At room temperature, the metal that remains liquid is:
questions.solution: Solution:		At room temperature, the metal that remains liquid is mercury.

questions.Question: A metal is exposed to the atmosphere for sometime. It becomes coated with green carbonate. The metal must be
questions.solution: Solution:		Copper forms a rich variety of compounds with oxidation states +1 and +2, which are often called cuprous and cupric, respectively. It does not react with water, but it slowly reacts with atmospheric oxygen forming a layer of brown-black copper oxide. In contrast to the oxidation of iron by wet air, this oxide layer stops the further, bulk corrosion. A green layer of verdigris (copper carbonate) can often be seen on old copper constructions, such as the Statue of Liberty, the largest copper statue in the world built using repoussé and chasing. Hydrogen sulphides and sulphides react with copper to form various copper sulphides on the surface. In the latter case, the copper corrodes, as is seen when copper is exposed to air containing sulfur compounds. Oxygen-containing ammonia solutions give water-soluble complexes with copper, as do oxygen and hydrochloric acid to form copper chlorides and acidified hydrogen peroxide to form copper(II) salts. Copper(II) chloride and copper combine to form copper(I) chloride.

questions.Question: One carat of diamond is equal to
questions.solution: Solution:		One carat of diamond is equal to 200 mg.

questions.Question: Carbon dioxide is
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon dioxide is a reducing agent.

questions.Question: Hardest allotrope of carbon is
questions.solution: Solution:		Diamond is a well known allotrope of carbon. The hardness and high dispersion of light of diamond make it useful for both industrial applications and jewelry. Diamond is the hardest known natural mineral.

questions.Question: Diamond is lustrous because
questions.solution: Solution:		Diamond is lustrous because its refractive index is high.

questions.Question: Dry ice is
questions.solution: Solution:		Dry ice is the solid form of carbon dioxide. It is used primarily as a cooling agent. Its advantages include lower temperature than that of water ice and not leaving any residue. It is useful for preserving frozen foods where mechanical cooling is unavailable.

questions.Question: The most volatile of the given liquids is
questions.solution: Solution:		Liquid Helium is the most volatile liquid.

questions.Question: The three elements most needed in common fertilisers are :
questions.solution: Solution:		Fertilizer (or fertiliser) is any organic or inorganic material of natural or synthetic origin (other than liming materials) that is added to a soil to supply one or more plant nutrients essential to the growth of plants. The three elements most needed in common fertilisers are Nitrogen. Potassium and Phosphorous.

questions.Question: Liquid Nitrogen boils at
questions.solution: Solution:		Liquid nitrogen is very cold! At normal atmospheric pressure, nitrogen is a liquid between 63 K and 77.2 K (-346°F and -320.44°F). Over this temperature range, liquid nitrogen looks much like boiling water. Below 63 K, it freezes into solid nitrogen. Because liquid nitrogen in a usual setting is boiling, its usual temperature is 77 K.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not a fertilizer?
questions.solution: Solution:		Calcium sulfate is a common laboratory and industrial chemical. In the form of -anhydrite (the nearly anhydrous form), it is used as a desiccant. It is also used as a coagulant in products like tofu. The main sources of calcium sulfate are naturally occurring gypsum and anhydrite which occur at many locations worldwide as evaporites.

questions.Question: Which of the following gases is mixed with oxygen for breathing by divers in aqua lungs?
questions.solution: Solution:		Trimix is a breathing gas consisting of oxygen, helium and nitrogen and is used in deep commercial diving, during the deep phase of dives carried out using technical diving techniques, and in advanced recreational diving

questions.Question: Major portion of the earth’s crust is mainly constituted by
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen is the most abundant element in the earth’s crust, comprising 46.6% or the crust by weight. Silicon 28%, aluminum 8.2%, iron 5.6%, calcium 4.2%, sodium 2.5%, magnesium 2.4%, potassium, 2.0%, and titanium 0.61% also comprise the crust. Given the abundance of oxygen and silicon, the silicates are the most abundant minerals in the earth’s crust.

questions.Question: In surgery, metal pins are used for joining together broken bones. These metal pins remain uncorroded in the body. What is the material of these pins?
questions.solution: Solution:		Titanium metal is important for its strength, low density and corrosion resistance. It has bitter corrosion resistance and less reactivity than aluminium. Hence, Titanium pins remains uncorroded in the body.

questions.Question: Name two elements that find wide application in transistor industry.
questions.solution: Solution:		A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify and switch electronic signals and electrical power. Semiconductor material (date first used): the metalloids germanium (1947) and silicon (1954) — in amorphous, polycrystalline and mono-crystalline form; the compounds gallium arsenide (1966) and silicon carbide (1997), the alloy silicon-germanium (1989), the allotrope of carbon graphene (research ongoing since 2004), etc.

questions.Question: Which one is the naturally occuring heaviest element?
questions.solution: Solution:		The heaviest naturally stable element is uranium, but over the years physicists have used accelerators to synthesize larger, heavier elements.

questions.Question: Which of the following will replace hydrogen from acids to form salts ?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the reactivity series , elements which are above of hydrogen can replace hydrogen. Hence Sodium will replace hydrogen from acids to form salts.

questions.Question: Periodic table contains how many periods
questions.solution: Solution:		Periodic table contains 7 periods.

questions.Question: Which one is the lightest element in the periodic table
questions.solution: Solution:		The lightest chemical element is Hydrogen and the heaviest is Hassium.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is most electronegative?
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon is most electronegative among the following.

questions.Question: Periodic table contains how many groups
questions.solution: Solution:		The s-, p-, and d-block elements of the periodic table are arranged into 18 numbered columns, or groups. The elements in each group have the same number of valence electrons.

questions.Question: Total number of elements in the Periodic table
questions.solution: Solution:		Total number of elements in the periodic table is 118.

questions.Question: Atoms having the same number of protons but different number of neutrons are called :
questions.solution: Solution:		Two atoms with the same atomic number, but different mass numbers (same number of protons, different number of neutrons), are called isotopes, or isotopic nuclides.

questions.Question: Chemical properties of isotopes
questions.solution: Solution:		Different isotopes of an element generally have the same physical and chemical properties. That's because they have the same numbers of protons and electrons.

questions.Question: Which of the following does the nucleus of an atom consists of?
questions.solution: Solution:		The nucleus of an atom consists of neutrons and protons, which in turn are the manifestation of more elementary particles, called quarks, that are held in association by the nuclear strong force in certain stable combinations of hadrons, called baryons.

questions.Question: The nucleus of an atom consists of
questions.solution: Solution:		The nucleus is a collection of particles called protons, which are positively charged, and neutrons, which are electrically neutral. Protons and neutrons are in turn made up of particles called quarks.

questions.Question: The mass number of a nucleus is
questions.optionA: Always less than its atomic number
questions.optionB: Always more than its atomic number
questions.optionC: Always equal to its atomic number
questions.optionD: Sometimes more and somtimes equal to its atomic number
questions.solution: Solution:		The mass number (A), is the total number of protons and neutrons in an atomic nucleus so sometimes more than and sometimes equal to its atomic number, depends upon no of neutrons.

questions.Question: White phosphorus is always kept under
questions.solution: Solution:		White phosphorus is highly reactive, and spontaneously ignites at about 30°C in moist air. It is usually stored under water, to prevent exposure to the air.

questions.Question: Milk is a colloidal system in which:
questions.optionC: Fat and water are dispersed in each other
questions.solution: Solution:		A colloid is a substance microscopically dispersed evenly throughout another substance. A colloidal system consists of two separate phases: a dispersed phase (or internal phase) and a continuous phase (or dispersion medium) in which the colloid is dispersed. A colloidal system may be solid, liquid, or gas. Milk is an emulsified colloid of liquid butterfat globules dispersed within a water-based solution.

questions.Question: An emulsion is a colloid of a
questions.solution: Solution:		An emulsion is a mixture of two or more liquids that are normally immiscible (unmixable or unblendable) owing to liquid-liquid phase separation. Emulsions are part of a more general class of two-phase systems of matter called colloids.

questions.Question: An emulsion is a colloidal solution of
questions.solution: Solution:		An emulsion is a colloidal solution of two liquids, one of which is an oil and the other one is water. For example, milk is an emulsion.

questions.Question: Colloids can be purified by
questions.solution: Solution:		Dialysis is the process which is used for the separation of crystalloids from a colloid by filtration or diffusion through parchment paper or animal membrane. The apparatus employed for this purpose is called dialyser. This process is based on the fact that membranes contain very small pores through which only dissolved molecules and ions of the true solution can pass readily.

questions.Question: Which one is the simplest form of alkane?
questions.solution: Solution:		The simplest alkane is methane. Methane contains only one carbon atom and four hydrogen atoms.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a natural source of hydrocarbon?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are three main natural sources of hydrocarbons: natural gas, petroleum and coal. Mica is a natural occurring mineral that is based on a collection of silicate minerals and composed of varying amounts of potassium, iron, aluminum, magnesium and water. It is widely used in the electrical industry.

questions.Question: The element with highest first ionisation energy is
questions.solution: Solution:		The ionization energy decreases from top to bottom in groups, and increases from left to right across a period. Thus, helium has the largest first ionization energy, while francium has one of the lowest.

questions.Question: In a period from Li to F, ionisation potential
questions.solution: Solution:		Ionization energy increases along a period with increase in atomic number. However, in the periodic table, going from left to right, while the Ionization Potential of Li is 5.4 eV, that of Be: 9.3 eV, B: 8.3 eV, C: 11.3 eV, N: 14.6 eV, O: 13.6 eV, and F: 17.0 eV.

questions.Question: In the periodic table of elements, on moving from left to right across a period, the atomic radius
questions.optionD: Does not follow a definite pattern
questions.solution: Solution:		In the periodic table of elements, on moving from left to right across a period, the atomic radius decreases.

questions.Question: Commercial nitric acid is coloured because it contains dissolved :
questions.solution: Solution:		Commercial nitric acid has a brown colour due to dissolved NO2. The procedure of bubbling dry air through warm commercial nitric acid, is to drive away the dissolved nitrogen dioxide so that the acid becomes colourless.

questions.Question: Choose the incorrect statement pertaining to organic compounds
questions.optionA: They have low melting and boiling points
questions.optionB: They do not dissolve in water
questions.optionD: They contain mainly carbon and hydrogen
questions.solution: Solution:		Typical organic compounds are combustible by nature as they contain carbon. Organic compounds mostly consist of carbon, hydrogen, halogen, and phosphorus.

questions.Question: The gas which emits from rice field is
questions.solution: Solution:		Rice paddy fields are a source of the GHGs carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O).

questions.Question: Ethylene is a ________ molecule.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ethylene is a nonpolar molecule.

questions.Question: The next higher homologue of C6H14 is
questions.solution: Solution:		The next higher homologue of C6H14 is C7H16.

questions.Question: Rock salt is a mineral containing
questions.solution: Solution:		Halite, commonly known as rock salt, is the mineral form of sodium chloride (NaCl). Halite forms isometric crystals. It commonly occurs with other evaporite deposit minerals such as several of the sulfates, halides, and borates.

questions.Question: Baking soda is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Baking soda is Sodium bicarbonate.

questions.Question: Sodium Carbonate is commonly known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium Carbonate is commonly known as Washing Soda.

questions.Question: Brine refers to :
questions.solution: Solution:		 Brine refers to water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt.

questions.Question: The chemical name of baking soda is
questions.solution: Solution:		The chemical name of baking soda is Sodium bicarbonate.

questions.Question: Which of the following gases is present under pressure in soft drinks?
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon dioxide is present under pressure in soft drinks.

questions.Question: If we burn graphite,
questions.solution: Solution:		If we burn graphite, no residue will be left.

questions.Question: Lead pencil contains
questions.solution: Solution:		Lead pencils contain graphite (a form of carbon), not lead. In fact, contrary to what many people believe, lead pencils never were made with lead. The ancient Romans used a writing device called a stylus.

questions.Question: Highest percentage of carbon is found in which form of coal?
questions.solution: Solution:		Highest percentage of carbon is found in anthracite.

questions.Question: The main source of carbon monoxide is
questions.solution: Solution:		The main source of carbon monoxide is transportation.

questions.Question: Oxide of sulphur present in the atmosphere are washed down by rains to cause :
questions.solution: Solution:		The oxide of Sulphur (Sulphur Dioxide) is washed down on earth as acid rain. It makes the soil acidic by lowering its pH; this affects plants and animals adversely. Acid rain contains H+, SO42- ions which when added to the soil leaches the nutrients from the soil. Acid rain renders the river or even ocean water acidic, thereby affecting marine animals adversely. Changes in pH of fresh water affect the reproduction and survival or many species or fish.

questions.Question: Supersonic jet causes pollution by thinning of
questions.solution: Solution:		Most commercial flights are confined to the troposphere, but high-level supersonic aircraft inject pollutants into the stratosphere, which leads to the thinning of the ozone layer. Of these nitrogen oxides are especially harmful.

questions.Question: The pollutant responsible for ozone holes is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Ozone depletion occurs when chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons—gases formerly found in aerosol spray cans and refrigerants—are released into the atmosphere.

questions.Question: Major gaseous pollutant of the thermal power station is
questions.solution: Solution:		A flue-gas stack is a type of chimney, a vertical pipe, channel or similar structure through which combustion product gases called flue gases are exhausted to the outside air. Flue gases are produced when coal, oil, natural gas, wood or any other fuel is combusted in an industrial furnace, a power plant’s steam-generating boiler, or other large combustion device. Flue gas is usually composed of carbon dioxide (CO2) and water vapor as well as nitrogen and excess oxygen remaining from the intake combustion air. It also contains a small percentage of pollutants such as particulate matter, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. The flue gas stacks are often quite tall, up to 400 metres (1300 feet) or more, so as to disperse the exhaust pollutants over a greater area and thereby reduce the concentration of the pollutants to the levels required by governmental environmental policy and environmental regulation.

questions.Question: The gas causing acid rain in an industrial area is
questions.solution: Solution:		Acid rain results when sulphur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOX) are emitted into the atmosphere and transported by wind and air currents.

questions.Question: Sour taste of ‘Coca Cola’ is due to the presence of
questions.solution: Solution:		Food-grade phosphoric acid (additive E338) is used to acidify foods and beverages such as various colas, but not without controversy regarding its health effects. It provides a tangy or sour taste and, being a mass-produced chemical, is available cheaply and in large quantities. The low cost and bulk availability is unlike more expensive seasonings that give comparable flavors, such as citric acid which is obtainable from citrus, but usually fermented by Aspergillusniger mold from scrap molasses, waste starch hydrolysates and phosphoric acid.

questions.Question: An acid having basicity one is
questions.solution: Solution:		The basicity of an acid is the number of hydrogen ions (H+) which can be produced by the ionization of one molecule of the acid in aqueous solution. For example, the basicity of hydrochloric acid is 1 since one molecule of HCl produces one H+ ion in solution. Similarly, the basicity of Disodium phosphate (Na2HPO4) is one since it has one H+ displaceable ion.

questions.Question: The acid present in red ants is
questions.solution: Solution:		Formic acid, systematically named methanoic acid, is the simplest carboxylic acid, and has the chemical formula HCOOH. It is an important intermediate in chemical synthesis and occurs naturally, most notably in some ants.

questions.Question: Bee sting contains
questions.solution: Solution:		Bee sting contains an acidic liquid.

questions.Question: Sweat contains water and ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sweat contains water and dissolved salts. Sweat consists of water and salt. Besides these it also consists of lactic acid, glucose, amino acid and urea.

questions.Question: Which of these acids is not organic in origin?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sulphuric acid is produced from sulfur, oxygen and water via the conventional contact process (DCDA) or the wet sulfuric acid process (WSA). Sulfuric acid can be produced in the laboratory by burning sulfur in air and dissolving the gas produced in a hydrogen peroxide solution.

questions.Question: Match the sourc in Column B with the product of Column A. (Product) Column B (Source)A. Formic acid1. LemonB. Citric acid 2. TamarindC. Tartaric acid3. Ants
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Saline soil contains
questions.solution: Solution:		Saline soil contains high concentration of salt.

questions.Question: Sour milk contains
questions.solution: Solution:		Sour milk contains Lactic acid.

questions.Question: Basicity of boric acid, H3BO3 is
questions.solution: Solution:		Basicity of boric acid, H3BO3 is 2.

questions.Question: What is the mass percentage of oxygen in carbon dioxide (CO2)?
questions.solution: Solution:		The mass percentage of oxygen in carbon dioxide is 72.7 %.

questions.Question: Number of 6.023 × 1023 atoms present in one mole of a gas at STP is
questions.solution: Solution:		Number of 6.023 × 1023 atoms present in one mole of a gas at STP is 6.023 × 1023.

questions.Question: The percentage of nitrogen present in ammonium sulphate is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Ammonium sulphate, (NH4)2SO4 contains 21% nitrogen as ammonium cations, and 24% sulfur as sulfate anions. It is an inorganic salt which is most commonly used as a soil fertilizer.

questions.Question: The value of Avogadro Number is
questions.solution: Solution:		The value of Avogadro Number is 6.023 × 1023.

questions.Question: Aqua regia is a 1 : 3 mixture, by volume, of
questions.optionA: Conc. nitric acid and conc. hydrochloric acid
questions.optionB: Conc. hydrochloric acid and conc. nitric acid
questions.optionC: Conc. nitric acid and conc. sulphuric acid
questions.optionD: Conc. sulphuric acid and conc. nitric acid
questions.solution: Solution:		Aqua regia or nitro-hydrochloric acid is a highly corrosive mixture of acids, a fuming yellow or red solution. The mixture is formed by freshly mixing concentrated nitric acid and hydrochloric acid, usually in a volume ratio of 1:3.
