questions.Question: The chemical name of 'Plaster of Paris' commonly used for setting broken bones is
questions.solution: Solution:		Plaster of Paris is the common name of Calcium Sulphate hemihydrate, with chemical formula: CaSO4.1/2H2O. Plaster of Paris is produced by heating gypsum to about 150°C.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is an example of a gel ?
questions.solution: Solution:		A gel is a solid, jelly-like material that can have properties ranging from soft and weak to hard and tough. Gels consist of a solid three-dimensional network that spans the volume of a liquid medium and ensnares it through surface tension effects. Shaving creams in a can are commonly dispensed as a foam or a gel.

questions.Question: A substance which readily forms colloidal solution in contact with water is called
questions.solution: Solution:		A colloidal dispersion in which the dispersed particles are more or less liquid and exert a certain attraction on and absorb a certain quantity of the fluid in which they are suspended is called as hydrophilic colloid. Molecules of a hydrophilic colloid have an affinity for water molecules and when dispersed in water become hydrated. Hydrated colloids swell and increase the viscosity of the system, thereby improving stability by reducing the interaction between particles and their tendency to settle. They may also possess a net surface electrical charge. The charge sign depends on the chemical properties of the colloid and the pH of the system. The presence of a surface charge produces repulsion of the charged particles and thus reduces the likelihood that the particles will adhere to one another and settle. Some examples of hydrophilic colloids used in pharmacy are acacia, methylcellulose, and proteins, such as gelatin and albumin.

questions.Question: Peptization is a process of
questions.solution: Solution:		Peptization or Deflocculation is the process responsible for the formation of converting precipitate into colloid by shaking with it an electrolyte. This is particularly important in colloid chemistry or for precipitation reactions in an aqueous solution.

questions.Question: What do you understand by the term Espuma ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Espuma is a Spanish term for froth or foam, and one that is created specifically with the use of a siphon bottle. Espuma is created mainly with liquid that has air incorporated in it to create froth. This is a specific term, since culinary foams may be attained through other means.

questions.Question: Cloud is a colloidal dispersion of
questions.optionA: Air in a dispersion medium of water
questions.optionB: Fog in a dispersion medium of water
questions.optionC: Mist in a dispersion medium of air
questions.optionD: Water drops in a dispersion medium of air
questions.solution: Solution:		Cloud is a colloidal dispersion of water drops in a dispersion medium of water.

questions.Question: The mass number of a nucleus is
questions.optionA: always less than its atomic number
questions.optionB: the sum of the number of protons and neutrons present in the nucleus
questions.optionC: always more than the atomic weight
questions.solution: Solution:		The mass number (A), is the total number of protons and neutrons ns) in an atomic nucleus so sometimes more than and sometimes equal to its atomic number, depends upon no of neutrons.

questions.Question: The inexpensive and commonly used variety of glass is called soda glass. It is called so because
questions.optionA: was used initially for making bottles of soda(carbonated drink)
questions.optionC: was initially used for storing sodium carbonate
questions.solution: Solution:		The inexpensive and commonly used variety of glass is called soda glass. It is called so because is made using soda(sodium carbonate).

questions.Question: The gas used in the manufacture of vanaspati from vegetable oil is
questions.solution: Solution:		Hydrogenation - to treat with hydrogen - is a chemical reaction between molecular hydrogen (H2) and another compound or element, usually in the presence of a catalyst. The process is commonly employed to reduce or saturate organic compounds. The largest scale application of hydrogenation is for the processing of vegetable oils (fats to give margarine and related spreads and shortenings). Typical vegetable oils are derived from polyunsaturated fatty acids (containing more than one carbon-carbon double bonds). Their partial hydrogenation reduces most but not all, of these carbon-carbon double bonds. Hydrogenation converts liquid vegetable oils into solid or semi-solid fats, such as those present in margarine.

questions.Question: The ionic radii of N3-, O2-, F- and Na+ follows the order
questions.solution: Solution:		The ionic radii of N3-, O2-, F- and Na+ follows the order N3- > O2- > F- > Na+

questions.Question: The graphite rods in the nuclear reactor
questions.optionA: react with U to release energy
questions.optionC: undergo combustion which triggers the nuclear fission
questions.optionD: convert fast moving neutrons into thermal neutrons
questions.solution: Solution:		In nuclear reactor graphite rods are used as moderator or controller. Application of moderator is to slow down the neutron and controller is to control the number of neutron.

questions.Question: The structure of (HPO3)3 is
questions.solution: Solution:		The structure of (HPO3)3 is cyclic.

questions.Question: Spontaneous change is one in which there is:
questions.solution: Solution:		Entropy and enthalpy together make a new quantity, the Free Energy which, under conditions of constant temperature and pressure, determines the direction of spontaneous change. All spontaneous processes have a negative change in free energy.

questions.Question: Which of the following kinds of spectroscopy can provide information on the energy difference between the initial and final states rather the energy levels involved in the transition?
questions.solution: Solution:		UV photoelectron spectroscopy can provide information on the energy difference between the initial and final states rather the energy levels involved in the transition.

questions.Question: When ice cubes are made, the entropy of water
questions.optionD: May either increase or decrease depending on the process used
questions.solution: Solution:		During formation of ice cubes orderedness increases, i.e., disorderness decreases, hence entropy decreases.

questions.Question: Warming ammonium chloride with sodium hydrochloride in a test tube is an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		Warming Ammonium Chloride with Sodium Hydroxide in a test tube is an example of an Open System.

questions.Question: Bleaching powder is used in drinking water as a/an
questions.solution: Solution:		Bleaching powder, CaOCl2 or calciumoxychloride is used to kill germs and bacteria of water because it contains chlorine element, which is good disinfecting agent.

questions.Question: The process of removing calcium and magnesium from hard water is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Softening is the process of removing the dissolved calcium and magnesium salts that cause hardness in water. Water softening is achieved either by adding chemicals that form insoluble precipitates or by ion exchange.

questions.Question: Hard water and soft water can be distinguished by using
questions.solution: Solution:		Hard water and soft water can be distinguished by using detergent.

questions.Question: Which method will be employed to test the hardness of water?
questions.solution: Solution:		Soap solution is used to measure the hardness of rain water, temporarily hard water and sea-water. Hard water does not form soap lather. This is because magnesium ions or calcium ions present in hard water react with soap to form calcium stearate or magnesium stearate and thus forms scum.

questions.Question: The purest form of water is
questions.solution: Solution:		The purest form of water is rain water.

questions.Question: Which of the following appeared to be with a significant potential for accumulation through food chains ?
questions.solution: Solution:		DDT appeared to be with a significant potential for accumulation through food chains.

questions.Question: Higher concentration of nitrogen dioxide in atmosphere air causes
questions.solution: Solution:		Higher concentration of nitrogen dioxide in atmosphere air causes bronchitis.

questions.Question: Which of the following in automobile exhaust can cause cancer?
questions.solution: Solution:		Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed during incomplete combustion. Domestic wood burning and road traffic are the major sources of PAHs. Exposure to PAH-containing substances increases the risk of cancer in humans. The carcinogenicity of PAHs is associated with the complexity of the molecule, i.e., increasing number of benzenoid rings, and with metabolic activation to reactive diol epoxide intermediates and their subsequent covalent binding to critical targets in DNA. Quantitative cancer risk estimates of PAHs as air pollutants are very uncertain because of the lack of useful, good-quality data.

questions.Question: White lung cancer is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Asbestosis, also called white lung, lung disease that is caused by the prolonged inhalation of asbestos fibres.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a man-made source of air pollution ?
questions.optionC: Bacterial action in soil and swamp areas
questions.solution: Solution:		Automobile exhaust is a man-made source of air pollution.

questions.Question: Atoms of same element having different mass numbers are called________
questions.solution: Solution:		Atoms of same element having different mass numbers are called isotopes.

questions.Question: How many neutrons does iron have?
questions.solution: Solution:		Iron has 30 neutrons.

questions.Question: The electronic configuration of an atom having atomic number ‘20’ is
questions.solution: Solution:		The electronic configuration of an atom having atomic number ‘20’ is 2, 8, 8, 2.

questions.Question: Nucleus of an atom consists of.
questions.solution: Solution:		The nucleus is a collection of particles called protons, which are positively charged, and neutrons, which are electrically neutral.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a nucleon?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleon is one of the particles that makes up the atomic nucleus. Each atomic nucleus consists of one or more nucleons, and each atom in turn consists of a cluster of nucleons surrounded by one or more electrons. There are two kinds of nucleon: the neutron and the proton. The mass number of a given atomic isotope is identical to its number of nucleons. Thus the term nucleon number may be used in place of the more common terms mass number or atomic mass number. Until the 1960s, nucleons were thought to be elementary particles, each of which would not then have been made up of smaller parts. Now they are known to be composite particles, made of three quarks bound together by the so-called strong interaction. The interaction between two or more nucleons is called inter-nucleon interactions or nuclear force, which is also ultimately caused by the strong interaction. (Before the discovery of quarks, the term “strong interaction” referred to just inter-nucleon interactions).

questions.Question: The addition of gypsum to portland cement helps in :
questions.optionD: Reduction in the cost of cement
questions.solution: Solution:		Portland cement clinker is a hydraulic material which shall consist of at least two-thirds by mass of calcium silicates, the remainder consisting of aluminium- and iron-containing clinker phases and other compounds. The ratio of CaO to SiO2 shall not be less than 2.0. The magnesium oxide content (MgO) shall not exceed 5.0% by mass. Cement sets when mixed with water by way of a complex series of chemical reactions still only partly understood. The different constituents slowly crystallise and the interlocking of their crystals gives cement its strength. Carbon dioxide is slowly absorbed to convert the portlandite (Ca(OH)2) into insoluble calcium carbonate. After the initial setting, immersion in warm water will speed up setting. Gypsum is added as an inhibitor to prevent flash setting.

questions.Question: Which gas is most stable at room temperature?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen (N2) is most stable at room temperature.

questions.Question: Which of the following is used as a preservative to protect processed food?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium metabisulphite is used as a preservative to protect processed food.

questions.Question: Chemical composition of cement is
questions.solution: Solution:		Chemical composition of cement is Limestone, Clay and Gypsum.

questions.Question: Which one of the following elements is used in the manufacture of fertilizers ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium are the three most common bases of fertilizers. Potash can be used to make potassium (K) fertilizers. All commercial potash deposits come originally from marine deposits and are often buried deep in the earth.
